title.rendered: New Name, Logo, and Packaging for Angelic Bakehouse by Shine United

content.rendered:
Established in 1969 as Cybros the Sprouted Bakehouse in Waukesha, WI, Angelic Bakehouse, as it was renamed this year, is self-credited as one of the first “champions of sprouted grains” offering a range of breads. Since being purchased in 2009 by a husband and wife team, the bread-maker has tripled its business and is now ready to expand with this new name, identity, and packaging designed by Madison, WI-based Shine United.

Meet Angelic Bakehouse. A name that reflects the purity of the ingredients used and processes applied when making every product. From a new logo and packaging to digital and social design, the entire brand presence is an honest manifestation of the product itself — wholesome and pure. And where the category is over-run with old-fashioned hearth and oven-related design, Shine took a fresh approach.

Provided text

The previous name and logo were definitely on the far side of the hippie axis when it comes to the aesthetics of health(ier) food with its drum-circle typography — I don’t even know what that means, but it felt good writing it. Anyway. The new logo and name are excellent and pair perfectly. The grain-stalk-winged “A” has a great, airy look to it and almost looks like a superhero emblem. The connection to angels and wings is clear but not annoyingly obvious. The typography in “ANGELIC” is clean, contemporary, and bold. I wish I could say the same for “BAKEHOUSE” but it seems another designer was in charge of that: the type selection is close enough to the one in the main name, yet it’s not. The “E”s are especially jarring. Nonetheless, it’s a strong logo. There is also a particular detail that I love about it: the meeting point of the grain stalks that serve as the crossbar of the “A” is the exact center of the full logo. That is so hot.

I’ve never been much of a fan of critiquing packaging, so I won’t start now. But I’ll just close with saying that that is one savory-looking set of bread bags. My favorite part is the band of logos on the opening of the bag. Overall, a great redesign obviously done with great care and attention to detail.
